content: hello everyone why lock here welcome
back this week we're gonna make a miniature pipe organ out of very cheap
materials that you probably already have laying around your house
don't forget the february-march guild build is going on I recently put up a
video for that on one more note in response to a lot of PM's I'm getting I
think a lot of you found me because of my recent episode 115 with the modular
industrial catwalks the sequel is coming it's actually
probably gonna be two because I have a hundred ideas that you guys gave me for
stuff to make I really want it to be a jam-packed episode of value on and do it
right that's why it's taking a little bit of time but it is coming rest
assured anyway let's go make the organ drinking straws just the common humble
plastic bendy drinking straw these are going to be the organ pipes first chop
one end at like 45 degrees and then cut straight at least 45 to 50 millimeters
down from the tip then fill it with some hot glue about halfway up should be fine
don't get in water too greatly speed up the cooling and hardening process and
then with another day of a hot glue just stick it onto some paper I use wax paper
here not necessary I don't know why I did that anyways make 12 of these and
then go outside and prime them with a matte primer I like krylon matte black
so here they are all primed up you can of course layers out however you want
I wanted a symmetric looking arrangement so I took the two tallest middle pipes
those are going to be 42 millimeters long measured that marked it pencil
shows up great on matte primer and then just chop it there with scissors now you
have a nice clean solid bottom of the pipe filled with glue and cleanly sliced
the other five pairs I just decreased in height three millimeters at a time paint
these up with the color of your choice I'm going to use a metallic silver and
we'll come back to the pipes at the end to make the main body I'm using double
corrugated cardboard but you could use anything a wooden block foam whatever is
your preference I cut two 1 by 2 inch rectangles and hot glue them together
then I spent hours trying to paint a good-looking wood texture before
thinking myself you know I've never really tried print and paste so let's
take a short cut tonight so I went to Google Image Search searched on the
seamless wooden texture and found one that I liked copy it paste it into
Microsoft Word or paint or Photoshop whatever you're comfortable with scale
it if you want to and print yeah so from there I just cut a strip of it and
wrapped it around the foundation using a glue stick then I cut another rectangle
this one a bit smaller at 3/4 inch by 1 and 3/4 inch and wrapped it the same way
small beads of hot glue to attach the small one to the big one like you see
here and then you might notice that the
corners and the edges of the paper show some white I used a brown sharpie to
cover those up now for the keyboard itself
I used chipboard if you're new to the channel this stuff is awesome it is my
go to graphics medium chipboard there's only in the description below I am an
Amazon affiliate so if you want a totally free way to support this channel
at no cost to you just use that specific link and I get a small kickback anyway
cut a strip that is a quarter inch by one in three-quarters of an inch and
then paint it white probably need two or three coats now this is hard to do
suspended in midair for the camera but you're going to take a black fine tip or
ballpoint pen and draw lines every two millimeters or so to show the white keys
that done take a black sharpie or other felt tip type a marker and draw the
black keys if you're not familiar with the pattern of a keyboard you put the
black keys on the lines and go draw to skip one draw three skip one and repeat
or just google image search it and from there you just hot glue this onto that
smaller part of the organ again with chipboard cut a two by half inch
rectangle paint it brown and we're gonna hot glue it to the top again chipboard
is awesome because it's kind of fibrous so even after acrylic paint it's still
gonna take glue very well measure out the center of that plank on top and make
a small pencil mark and now we attach the pipes since they're already filled
with hot glue I basically just use the tip of the hot glue gun to reheat that
flat end that's already there don't squeeze any extra glue on there or if
you do just a tiny tiny little bit use the tip to reheat it give it a twirl to
kill any wisps and then attach it to the top taking care that it's straight up
and down continue and attach all the pipes in this manner again I got lazy
with the detail work google image search sheet music picked one I liked copy
pasted and printed and from chipboard just a small half-inch by 5/8 inch
rectangle paint it up Brown and attach the sheet music with a glue stick
to attach this to the organ I just put a healthy blob of hot glue on the back
towards the bottom and set it in place the hot glue will ooze down and contact
the organ forming a bond with a music ledger none of its squeezing out the
front this way very nice clean look and we're about to go to the table to see
the final product but real quick some reminders if you like what you're about
to see please don't hesitate to hit that like button subscribe reminders etc etc
there is a link in the description below from my Amazon storefront easy free way
to support the channel if you want just buy your stuff through that link and for
all you 3d printers out there why LOX crafting vids is sponsored by
Heroes Horde which has an excellent range of high-quality models including
but not limited to Altru tiles lines which are open lock compatible also
check out my modules over on the DMS guild and remember $3 patrons get free
copies of all my releases oh I forgot real quick couple lessons learned here
was my first attempt at this project it was gonna be a clip on when I realized
it doesn't need to be nothing about this feature requires it at beyond a wall
unlike a window or a door or the other dozens of clip ons we've made on this
channel in the past so if you want it next to a wall you just put it next to a
wall also you can see this was a failed attempt at a rich mahogany finish
actually it was my fourth failed attempt and it's why I switched to print and
paste and here another one I built see these ugly moorings between the pipes I
tried to use super glue to secure the pipes together to hopefully give them
more strength well it did make them stronger but it's also really ugly I
also found that just hot gluing them on independently they're plenty strong
enough it's not like we're gonna throw this thing against the wall also look at
how ugly it is where the pipes meet the organ that's because I glued them on
before painting much harder to do by chopping the pipes down after the filled
with glue and painting them before attaching you get a nice clean result
which we will go and take a look at now first we'll throw out some dungeon tiles
here I'll just build a small temple room of some sort and then also some other
clip ons for contexts I'll put cards on the screen for some of these other
projects you might be interested in there's the stained glass windows from
last time episode 118 a couple of pillars and some card stock minis and
here it is in all its glory the finished product again that detail work
just shortcuts print and paste love it wish I had tried it before now we'll
just paint around the room here and look at things in context I don't have much
more to say it kind of speaks for itself I said you probably have the stuff
laying around your house if you don't want to buy chipboard it's the stuff at
the back of a legal pad that grayish brownish fibrous board it's like a
sixteenth of an inch thick that's chipboard so if you have a legal pad you
can harvest it from there if you liked this particular project here's two more
that you should go check out right now also enjoy this month's community
showcase and don't forget to subscribe and click that bell reminder icon I am
why lock thanks for joining me and I'll see you next time
